channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Remote Modern Perl, 2-3 month project, $50/hr
item.description: We need a few stand-out developers to help a client with a one-off project. Youâ€™ll be working as part of an experienced remote Perl team with strong architectural skills and Modern Perl experience, helping their clients deliver customer-focused features. Youâ€™ll need to be independent, and able to deliver high-quality work on time.

item.title: Namaste and a Beach Day - Perl Position in California
item.description: Drab walls. Fluorescent lighting. A window overlooking the parking lot and Tedâ€™s rusty old Corollaâ€”does this sound like your nine-to-five nightmare? Then you donâ€™t want to miss this opportunity in beautiful Irvine, California, where your new office has views of the coast, the sea, and the Saddleback. Hello, mountain majesty!

item.title: Put your Perl skills into action in a young, green city that leaves more greenbacks in your pocket
item.description: Youâ€™ll be working for a Pittsburgh-based hosting company, well-known and well-respected within Perl circles. Serving over 120 countries worldwide and with their skin in the game for a quarter century, youâ€™ll be joining a squad with a smorgasbord of coding talent helping a plethora of businesses at scale.

item.title: Front-end focus for a full stack Perl developer
item.description: If youâ€™re a full stack developer whose interest leans more towards front-end work, this role is a great opportunity for you to sharpen and deepen your front-end skills while still keeping your toes in the back-end world of Perl.

item.title: Love independent music? Hipster not a dirty word to you? Drive forward independent music with Perl.
item.description: Small team with a startup-ish feel, even though weâ€™ve been around for an age. Weâ€™re not VC funded, weâ€™re in this for the long-haul - we want to make a difference. Strongly motivated to ensure that artists and labels are getting a fair deal. We all love music, occasionally the office will host a (fairly niche) gig downstairs.

item.description: David Game College, 31 Jewry St, London EC3N 2ET

item.description: August 16-17, 2019 FlÃ¶rli Olten, Switzerland

item.title: Talking with Tech Leads
item.description: Transitioning from developer to tech lead is not simple at all. Many pitfalls, many surprises. This presentation of Patrick along with all the references he mentioned is an excellent source of help.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Testing Powershell applications with Perl6 and Sparrow6
item.description: Step-by-step instructions about how to test Powershell modules using Perl6 and Sparrow6.

item.title: Six slices of pie
item.description: Damian revealing the secret who gets the biggest slice. Find out how he did it in style.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 18
item.description: Roger writings has also impressed me, specially the way he explains the feature in block. This makes very it easy to follow what he is doing. Great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 18: Priority Queues and Binary Heaps In Perl 6
item.description: In this blog, Laurent discussing how Binary Heap can help to solve the Priority Queues task. This itself can be passed the best guide for Binary Heap. Great writing skill, I must admit.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge # 18: Longest Common Substrings, Priority Queues, and a Functional Object System
item.description: Laurent starting with simple solution and then moving on sharing String::LCSS solution. The best part of the blog is how he wrote Perl5 solution mimicking Perl6.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 018/2: Priority Queue
item.description: In this second blog of the week, Choroba shares his journey to sove the Priority Queues task. You can't afford to miss it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 018/1: Longest Common Substring
item.description: In this blog, E. Choroba, discussing the first task "Longest Common Substring". I loved the way he modularise the solution that makes it so easy to follow.

item.title: Substrings and Queues with Perl 6
item.description: Arne's blog make the learning of Perl6 feature simple and easy to follow. Highly recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 018
item.description: Adam use of Class::Struct brought back good old memories. This is the beauty of weekly challenge that you are free to experiment with different ideas. You must read the blog.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 018
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 019
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: The Perl Language Family
item.description: Explore the family of The Perl Language.

item.title: Board update to SoC incident
item.description: Further update by TPF to SoC incident.

item.title: next Math::Matrix releases
item.description: Herbert discussing the next release of Math::Matrix.

item.title: Windows and Perl
item.description: Chase Whitener shares the relationship between Windows and Perl.

item.title: It's time to consider avoiding IP fragmentation in the DNS
item.description: Do you manage DNS? Then this is for you.

item.title: Swiss Perl Workshop 2019 - Less Than One Month
item.description: See you all in Olten on the 16th August 2019.

item.title: London Perl Workshop - 2019
item.description: The LPW is as usual FREE for all and happening on Saturday 19th October 2019.

item.title: Make what matters stick! StickerYou has an exclusive discount for all Perl Weekly subscribers
item.description: Need to brand everything with stickers, even your personal hydration bottle and coffee mug? At StickerYou.com you can create premium waterproof stickers in any size, shape, and order quantity. Whether youâ€™re a freelancer or aspiring entrepreneur, StickerYou makes it easy for you to stick your logo on everything and create brand awareness, or just to make stickers for personal expression, whether humorous or to support a cause. Use code PERL10 at checkout for a 10% discount on your order.

item.title: #418 - London Perl Workshop - 2019
item.description:
Hi there

Finally the London Perl Workshop 2019 is officially announced. Please come along and enjoy FREE one day technical conference on Saturday 19th October 2019. If you are planning to attend the workshop then please note that the venue has changed this time. The new address is David Game College, 31 Jewry St, London - EC3N 2ET.

They are now accepting talk proposals. So don't delay any further and submit your proposal asap. Or if you just want to attend the workshop then I would recommend you register your intention. It would help the organisers to know in advance how many attendees are coming, so that they can plan accordingly.

Have a great week ahead and enjoy reading the newsletter.
